"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." "According to the United Nations, economic and social factors contribute to the spread of HIV/AIDS, infecting an average of 16,000 people daily. Debt crisis in impoverished countries leads to more money spent on debt repayment than on HIV/AIDS prevention. Structural adjustment programs impose harmful policies like user fees at medical clinics, hindering prevention and treatment programs." User fees at health clinics in impoverished countries, due to structural adjustment programs, have led to decreased attendance at STD clinics by 35-60%. This, along with budget cuts, contributes to the spread of HIV/AIDS. Labor migration caused by these programs has increased HIV transmission rates in several African countries. The pandemic will result in millions of orphaned children, straining global resources. United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan highlighted the destructive impact of AIDS in 1999. In 1999, United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan emphasized the devastating impact of AIDS, comparing it to warfare. Many heavily indebted poor countries in Sub-Saharan Africa are facing catastrophic loss of life and economic decline due to the HIV/AIDS pandemic. The G-8 countries decided to reduce the debt of qualifying nations by $100 billion, benefiting only 22 countries with a 26% reduction in annual debt service. The Congress enacted section 596 of the Foreign Operations, Export Financing, and Related Programs Appropriations Act, 2001, demonstrating political commitment to eliminate user fees for primary health care and education. Multilateral and bilateral debt cancellation linked to HIV/AIDS control would have minimal impact on creditor country taxpayers and budgets. The United States provided $435,000,000 in fiscal year 2001 for debt cancellation for HIV/AIDS prevention and care, encouraging international financial institutions to match efforts for burden sharing. SEC. 2. Multilateral debt cancellation efforts for countries eligible under the HIPC initiative or heavily affected by HIV/AIDS. The Secretary of the Treasury will direct the US Executive Directors at the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund to advocate for debt cancellation for eligible countries under the HIPC Initiative or heavily affected by HIV/AIDS, ensuring that the savings are used for poverty reduction in a fair and transparent process involving various stakeholders. The US Executive Directors at the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund are directed to advocate for debt cancellation for eligible countries affected by HIV/AIDS. This includes encouraging countries to use savings from debt cancellation for HIV/AIDS response and health priorities. The US Executive Directors are directed to advocate for debt cancellation for eligible countries affected by HIV/AIDS, encouraging the use of savings for health priorities. Institutions can use reserve accounts or net income to offset the costs of debt cancellation. SEC. 3. OPPOSITION TO USER FEES FOR PRIMARY EDUCATION OR PRIMARY HEALTH CARE. The Secretary of the Treasury will oppose any program at the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund that includes user fees for primary education or health care. SEC. 4. ANTICORRUPTION STRATEGIES. The Secretary of the Treasury will develop strategies to counter corruption in specified countries. SEC. 5. REPORTS. SEC. 5. REPORTS. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit a report to relevant committees within a year of this Act's enactment, detailing progress in debt cancellation efforts and the impact on funding for HIV/AIDS programs. Recommendations for ensuring accountability in the use of savings from debt cancellation should also be included. In this Act, the term "G-8 countries" refers to a group of 8 major economic powers for economic cooperation. "Heavily affected by HIV/AIDS" means a country with at least 3% HIV/AIDS incidence or a national health emergency declaration. The "Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) Initiative" provides highly concessional assistance to eligible countries. The term "HIV/AIDS" refers to infection with the human immunodeficiency virus, including acquired immune deficiency syndrome.
